review_title: CatWoman, Pleasantly Surprised, Better Than Expected, Bashing The Film Is All About Flavor Of The Month Popularity

review_detailed_main: There are films so bad that they actually manage to achieve an entertainment value all of their own. And then there are films so bad that they are just bad. Catwoman falls squarely into the latter category. After Michelle Pfeiffer's revelatory turn as Catwoman in Batman Returns, many waited anxiously to see a re-teaming between her and Tim Burton in a separate film. Sadly, that did not happen. Instead, we get this cheesy, congealed mess, which feels like it is still in the development stage. Halle Berry does the honors this time as a mousy woman, who mystically survives a deadly experience and returns with feline powers. Her story feels like an incredibly limp and aimless rehash of what Batman Returns did much better. Berry, crammed into a ludicrous outfit that looks like a cross between S&M bondage and a cheap bikini, plays the role like she is a frustrated runway model. The sequence where she balances cat-like on furniture in her apartment while chatting nonchalantly on the phone is particularly laughable. There is no edge to her work here - whereas Pfeiffer's Catwoman was a woman on a mission of revenge, Berry's Catwoman seems oddly aimless. The supporting cast does not help. Frances Conroy shows up briefly in an embarrassing role as some sort of librarian who has to explain Berry's newfound powers to her. Alex Borstein is intolerable as Berry's typically loud-mouthed friend/co-worker. Benjamin Bratt is unimpressive as the cop who falls for Berry resulting in non-existent chemistry. And for the villain of the piece, we get a diabolical cosmetic queen, played by a shell-shocked Sharon Stone. To be fair, early in the film when her husband replaces her with a much younger woman, Stone does manage one or two affecting moments as a woman whose youth and glory days are falling by the wayside, but said depth evaporates quick. A late plot twist with Stone seems to come out of no where and she never seems much of a match for Berry. It may have been helpful if she had a character that would have allowed her to go over the top, but the character even on paper does not seem especially notable. There are literally no action pieces that stand-out and whoever is responsible for that ear-shattering warble that passes for music throughout the film should be throttled. Sadly, the film never achieves the level of so bad it is fascinating. Rather it is so bad it is just plain boring.

Don't waste your time. Catwoman was truly awful.

What a disappointment. In the tradition of almost all comic book movies of late, a huge let down.

Patience Phillips is a stereotypical overly meek and klutzy woman. She discovers a half-arsed conspiracy and is killed for it. An Egyptain mau cat (who's apparently immortal) resurrects her and she becomes... Catwoman.

The action is nonexistent until about one hour and fifteen minutes into the film. It's all talking, talking, talking, lots of female empowerment crap. Don't get me wrong, I'm called a feminist a lot, but sometimes can't we just say a woman kicks ass because she kicks ass? Does it have to be for a better reason? And can't a woman just sleep with a man because she wants to? Why must sex be about something bigger?

The by-play with Benjamin Bratt is lukewarm, and Alex Borstein's scenes as Patience's best friend are so strange they should have been cut.

Catwoman doesn't kill anybody when she should. Why? Because killing is wrong and good guys don't.

It was like I was watching five music videos instead of a movie. 3. Some of the worst dialogue I've EVER heard in a movie. 4. The director airbrushed Halle Berry and Sharon Stone in EVERY scene. I'm not even sure Halle Berry even starred in the movie: I think it may have been an entire computer generated person that looked like her. 5. The costumes. Even the normal clothes look terrible. And Sharon Stone in all white? She looks HIDEOUS! 6. Worst camera action sequences EVER. Even the part where Catwoman has the whip and is kicking some butt the director cuts the scene up so it's hard to tell what is going on. The good things? 1. I had a free movie ticket. 2. The real cats. And the CGI cat they have isn't so bad looking either. 3. The opening sequence with all kinds of cool pictures of cats and catwomen. Not even campy fun like I had hoped. Blech.

I can only assume that the writers had never even picked up a Catwoman comic, or indeed any Bat-verse comic featuring the title character. As the character has absolutely NO resemblance to the Catwoman from the comic books.

All they have done with this movie is use the title to lure in unsuspecting fans. But lets forget a minute about this, and look at it just as a film. Its still awful, very weak storyline, badly over the top acting by Sharon Stone as the villain and Halle Berry is wasted on this movie in the title role. In any case, while this movie wasn't nearly as good as it could have been, I don't believe it was nearly as bad as some have suggested and I have rated it accordingly. Slightly below average.

Halle Berry does a good job at portraying the dual character of Patience Phillips (shy, coy, a bit of a push over) and Catwoman (strong, confident, focused). I don't see any actress who could've done better.

The story line is less good. I liked the details about the "Catwomen" through history though.

Sharon stone was campy but still great to watch.

The action/fight sequences are really good too. Very nicely choreographed.

The Catwoman costume was cheesy and I actually "purr-fered" her black leather motorcycle outfit.

Cheesy/campy stuff you may enjoy on a slow afternoon when there is nothing better to watch, but NOT as bad as some would lead you to believe.

That doesn't mean I didn't feel plainly insulted by the garbage that this film tried to pass off as watchable. One can plainly see just by looking at this movie how horrible it is. The movie makers seem to have been trying to take the cheesiness of the final batman movie (which, might I add, made it bad) and mix it with a blatant feminist 'a-woman-is-as-good-as-a-man' mentality. The result of this cross-pollination is a blossom of something that goes far and beyond the level of asininity that any work of media should ever attempt.

Halle Berry, who I don't like to begin with, acts about as well as a freshman high school student in their first school play (I wonder if she pictures the audience naked when she gets nervous?). Often times, what can help a movie recover from a poor lead are it's supporting actors. However, if by supporting actors, one means actors that help support the lead and tell the story well... then this movie had slim to no chance of recovery. Particularly rank were the performances of Sharon Stone (who always seems to be a detriment to whatever movie that was unfortunate enough to cast her) and Frances Conroy (who makes it feel like her character would do better as the insane Seer from J.K. Rowling's writing and not as the wiser woman she is supposed to be portraying). Benjamin Bratt seems to be the only one doing a halfway decent job of acting, and that is most likely due to the fact that he is once again cast as the same thing he seems to be in every work he does: a cop. With a cast that obviously doesn't have their heart in the work that they do, one can't help but wonder why they are even doing it. And that isn't even mentioning the poor writing and hideous (yes, HIDEOUS) costume design of Catwoman herself.

It certainly makes me yearn for the days of yore, when Michelle Pfeiffer played a Catwoman who was more about the crime, or the 'hunt' if you will, than about the possible feminist aspects of being a strong and independent woman. The times when feline prowlers didn't have to prove themselves, and had the nine lives to back them up.

review_title: Marginally better than being put in front of a firing squad.
review_detailed_main:
How to describe this movie? It's a tough question. I could go with something pictorial, like a giant pile of manure covered in a swarm of buzzing flies, or try to invoke some sort of description based upon the booing and jeering audience in the cinema when I saw this. But those would not be good enough. No, this movie left me feeling at the end of it as if it had just murdered my entire family, and then subjected me to a couple of millennia of Abu Ghraib-styled torture.

Just what is it that provokes such vitriolic hatred? The movie is just flawed, from start to finish. I know from experience not to expect too much from American superhero flicks, but this makes "Batman and Robin" look like a masterpiece of modern film-making. The script is embarrassingly clichéd and bad, the cinematography is average at best, and Halle Berry's acting is about as wooden as the contents of a lumber yard. Apart from Ms Berry, all of the other actors here, mostly a collection of Hollywood wannabes and has-beens, overact to a degree that would make William Shatner blush with embarrassment.

Some people might think it slightly silly that I'd take offence at going to see tripe like this, but when you think about it, the millions of dollars that were spent on the bevy of special effects in this film (an ironic term, since not a single one of them is very special at all), could have been spent on cancer research, feeding starving African children, or, perhaps my favourite, actually putting together a decent film that people will watch out of something other than a sick sense of fascination with bad cinema.

This movie has bad CGI, terrible editing and nothing to do with Catwoman.

She doesn't even have her real name. They tried to make the character of Catwoman a mask who was worn by many throughout the years. Everything is cat-related even though the original character doesn't even have to do that much with them. She just likes cats and has a cat-costume.

Speaking of her costume, it's terrible. In this movie, they just made a sl*t out of Catwoman.

There is also this hate against men in this movie which is just bizarre.

If ever there was a more hated comic book adaptation than this Halle Berry helm mess, please point it out to me. And there are a truckload of reasons why this movie is considered such an abysmal flick. Let's first start with the story which is not only idiotic and lazily rendered but takes nothing from the source character. Catwoman has been around since the 1940's, building a long and detailed history of which there is a lot to choose from. So when Warner Bros. decided to green light the film, they subsequently threw all that out the window and replaced it with a plot that resembles The Devil Wears Prada (2006) mixed with Monkey Business (1952). Though, don't worry there's some Egyptian cat God mumbo-jumbo wedged in to make the action make cursory sense.

Patience (Berry) works for a cosmetics company who is about to release a new skin cream line which has some interesting side-effects. Patience finds out but is drowned before she can notify anyone. Washed up on the shores of an unnamed city, Patience is revived by a magical Mau cat thus giving Patience cat-like abilities. She then uses those abilities to dress-up in a slinky leather costume and fight the CEO of the company Laurel (Sharon Stone) before she releases her skin cream to the masses.

Let's assume you know nothing about Catwoman and thus don't care that the story of the film is almost offensively derivative from the source material. The film is still a jumbled mess of overt plot holes, conspicuously broad characterizations and a particularly fearless performance from Halle Berry who doesn't quite yet know she's about to be put down. Her performance is so emotionally invested in the story and physically over-the-top that you can't help but feel bad for her. Truly, this film is a disaster for all involved.

Contrary to the movie's general horrible reputation, I actually enjoyed watching this movie. This film is probably "Catwoman" in name only, a departure from her true purpose as the sly, sometimes evil, cat burglar, as intended by DC Comics and creator Bob Kane. In this movie, we have Patience Phillips, played by Halle Berry, stumbling upon a plot to get people to buy this beauty cream; you keep on using it, your skin is smooth and strong like marble, and if you stop using it, your skin disintegrates. At the course of the events afterward (I do not want to provide any spoilers), Phillips becomes Catwoman.

Catwoman's mission to foil the villain's plot portrays her as an actual hero in the movie, rather than the crafty cat burglar she originally is in the comic book. This probably upset true comic book fans, for Catwoman was not given her true form in this film, contrary to what what Michelle Pfieffer did to the role in "Batman Returns." Pfeiffer delivered a solid performance as Catwoman and stayed true to form-portrayed as a burglar and a nemesis to Batman, but also has a love interest for the Cape Crusader and reluctant at times to commit crimes, making her more like an anti-hero rather than a villain. Berry portrayed the character more like a superhero, and bears almost no resemblance to the comic book character. In addition, probably the movie's sometimes cheesy dialog and campy special effects contributed to this film's poor reviews. Aside from that, I personally think the action is quite good, the movie is fast-paced, the plot is followed well, the subplot of how a woman can turn into a Catwoman is interesting and Sharon Stone gave a quite devious performance as the villain. The only problem I had was that her role was not emphasized enough; the producers should of depicted her actually showing her crafty self and committing evil deeds, like the villains did in the Batman movies.

In addition, a picture of Michelle Pfieffer in her Catwoman outfit was briefly seen in Orphelia Powers' house, which meant that Patience Phillips is merely "another" Catwoman.

Overall, a pretty exciting and action-packed movie. My favorite scene is when Berry storms into her neighbor's apartment, furious of his overbearing parties, silences everybody by squirting water in his loudspeakers and jumps on him.

So, with this movie, you may like it, you may detest it. I just treat this as a movie involving another Catwoman in the Batman/DC Ccmics universe.

Grade B-

review_title: This One Needs More Than Nine Lives
review_detailed_main:
What a nightmare. Somebody pinch me and wake me up. That's what I kept thinking while watching this movie, which turned out to be a truly painful experience. And I'm not generally a conspiracy theorist, but after enduring "Catwoman," directed by Pitof (who? who?), I'm convinced that someone (or ones) are out to sabotage the careers of both Halle Berry and Sharon Stone (not to mention Benjamin Bratt). It's one thing to set out to make a "B" movie, but to waste such talent and beauty through sustained incompetence (yes, sustained, this movie wasn't filmed in a single day, was it? Come to think of it, maybe it was...) is nothing short of criminal (cinematically speaking).

I do not like to dwell on the negative aspects of any film, and I always attempt to seek out the positive (even most bad movies have something good in them, though you often have to look hard and deep to find it), but in fairness to Halle Berry, it must be noted how badly the script, editing, graphics and visual f/x, choreography and the director-- especially the director-- failed her here.

This misfire shouldn't allow us to forget Berry's excellent performances in such films as "Introducing Dorothy Dandridge" and "Monster's Ball," for which she deservedly was awarded an Oscar for Best Actress. The extent of her talent is undeniable and evidenced by the fact that her presence alone can add the necessary spark and elevate the stature of movies like "Bulworth" and "Die Another Day." So the million dollar question is, how did she wind up in this embarrassment? She (as well as the audience) deserves better. Obviously, she put her trust in the wrong people this time around, and at the top of that list is the "director" of this mishmash, Pitof.

I guess the lesson here is that even a major star should be wary when approached with a project that's been placed in the hands of someone whose name sounds like one of those ridiculous vanity plates you try to figure out while sitting at a red light and staring at the car in front of you. To put this as nicely as possible, Pitof (who? what does that MEAN?) didn't have a clue about what to do with this film, and especially with his actors. How could this have happened? He's given all the ingredients (Berry, Stone, Bratt, big budget) to make a prize winning cake and he turns out a lump unfit for consumption.

Add to Pitof's incompetence a laughably bad script (even the ability on the part of the viewer to suspend disbelief won't help with this one), bad editing and exceptionally poor computer graphics and visual f/x that look like something left over from the Stone Age of technology (when Catwoman is bounding and leaping about it has the appearance of an early generation video game; she looks more like a frog than a cat) you have a film that should be expunged from the resumes of everyone involved.

But, like I said, even a bad movie can have a high note if you look for it, which brings me to the only redeeming aspect of this film, the performance by Alex Borstein as Sally, one of Catwoman's co-workers. Best known as the voice of Lois Griffin in TVs "The Family Guy," Borstein has a charismatic presence that, within the context of this film at any rate, outshines even Berry and Stone. Better off for all concerned had this movie been titled "Sally," with Borstein given top billing and accordant screen time.

Unfortunately, too, for all concerned, "Catwoman" will enjoy it's full nine lives on the shelves of video stores everywhere. Just keep in mind, when you come to this shelf, pick up "The Cat's Meow," "The Cat In the Hat," "Cat People." "Cat On A Hot Tin Roof," or anything with "Cat" in the title that isn't followed by "Woman." Take it from me, you'll feel a lot better in the morning.

review_detailed_main:
I finally ended up watching "Catwoman" for the "How Did This Get Made" podcast, about terrible films, and I have to say, this one really lives up to its reputation as being nearly unwatchable.

Patience Phillips (Halle Berry) unwittingly discovers that the cosmetics firm she's working for is producing an addictive product that will kill people. She's murdered by agents of co-owner Laurel Hedare (Sharon Stone) but brought back to life by magic cats and imbued with enhanced speed and agility. Along with a cop, Tom Lone (Benjamin Bratt) Patience investigates her own 'death' and tries to stop the company before the product hits the wider market.

This truly lives up to its awful status. It's a boring, unambitious story with terrible performances, an awful script, bad CGI and horrible dated music. All of those criticism pale though in comparison with the movies ultimate problem, director Pitof takes his artistic bent way too far and his constantly moving camera renders the whole effort unwatchable.

There are some other aspects of the film that I might have liked, Alex Borstein is playing a fun "best friend" role, liked a toned-down version of her character from "Mrs Maisel" and I like Frances Conroy in other things. Sharon Stone is having a well-deserved renaissance now after this (and "Basic Instinct 2") looked like a death knell for her career. She's not actually that bad here but made to look ridiculous by the script. Her criminal plan is one of the least sane I've ever heard, as if when people start dropping dead no other scientist is going to be able to piece together that it's their product.

Often emotions are heightened when a film is new and either excessive praise or criticism can be edged away over time, but "Catwoman" is one film entirely deserving of its initial scorn and, if anything, has aged even worse.

review_title: Catwoman makes coughing up a hairball more enticing.
review_detailed_main: I have no words. I heard the chitter and the chatter, with many deeming this superhero disaster to be one of the worst films of all time. To say I agree would be an understatement. Holy leather catnip! This was torturous! Patience, a designer for a cosmetic company, is killed after witnessing the side-effects of their product. She is then (stay with me now) brought back to life by a cat who breathes on her corpse, granting her agile abilities of a cat. Thus becoming Catwoman. Completely disregarding its source material, Pitof's adaptation is "Purrfectly" terrible in every way. The story is quite simply nonsensical. A cat foresees the fate of Patience and decides to "test her" before choosing her to hone the powers of Catwoman. The eponymous anti-hero is not just the nickname for a jewellery thief. Oh no no! Pitof has better ideas! Catwoman is actually an entity of some kind that has been passed down since the Egyptians, bestowing the user the ability to climb walls, leap gracefully, devour fish and cat food, rub their nose in catnip and hiss at dogs. Quite literally embodying a cat (giving Patience a complete personality change). Why? Who actually thought this was a good idea!? Was it Halle Berry who nearly destroyed her career the same year as winning her coveted Oscar? Nope. Was it Sharon Stone who, much like her character, attempts to stay relevant and youthful? Perhaps. What about the overuse of horrific human visual effects that caused me to hiss at the screen? Nearly. The dull story that thinks it metaphorically showcases the negative connotations of using makeup? "Purrrhaps". Was it Pitof? Oh, definitely. The clichéd romance, plot conveniences and unusual addition of an R&B pop soundtrack made for an already outdated experience. But the sheer amount of quick cuts during the action sequences were unforgivable. Physically making me feel nauseous. To be honest with you I could go on and on and on, but you don't want to hear me drone on about how bad this disaster is. Everyone involved should be ashamed. Who even says "meowww!" after a fight?

review_title: Great ideas but too little value to outweigh such blunt tactlessness
review_detailed_main:
There comes a point where simply reading about cinematic infamy isn't enough, and you have to see it for yourself. 'Ishtar,' 'North,' and 'Showgirls' are all sad examples, and Pitof's much-maligned adaptation of a beloved comic book character is another. Before even watching the movie proper there's a lot to think about, and setting aside the end result, I appreciate the thought and effort that went into this. Myths, legends, and folklore from across all eras and cultures have centered around that truly superior terrestrial life form, the cat; this character is nothing if not an easy symbol for female empowerment, individuality, and a fight against oppressive systems. The writers try to play with these ideas in part, and also weave in themes of extreme corporate and capitalist malfeasance, and sexism. I admire the notion of protagonist Patience being effectively transformed as she takes on a new persona, going from meek and nervous to confident and brash; I take no issue with the way this rendition of a classic character is separated from the wider lore in which she's otherwise based - I see no reason why such a figure couldn't be treated as her very own person. Angus Strathie's guiding tack behind the infamous costume makes perfect sense to me. All this is well and good. And none of it saves 'Catwoman' from the significant problems that weigh it down and have helped it to earn a label as one of the worst films ever made.

There is a tawdry, dire, overbearing, excruciating lack of tact or nuance characterizing this feature. There's a false, waxy sheen layered over the fundamental image; every instance of CGI is simply unbearable, including not least that first moment when our protagonist has her "awakening," and too many illustrations of her "powers." That CGI, the cinematography, the editing, and a great deal of the writing and direction - dialogue, scenes, characters, plot development, and so on - are forthright, over the top, and even overzealous to the point of being not fun, but hopelessly tacky. This also applies to any action sequences, filled with zip, zest, bombast, style, and a transparent intended "cool factor," but also invariably tiresome for lack of any dynamics or subtlety. There are actually some really terrific ideas here, including the concept of Patience taking on feline traits and behavior, and these lend themselves to genuine delight and laughter at times. The fact that such wit and humor feels kind of out of place in an action flick, well, that's highly unfortunate. I like that Catwoman's fighting style is informed by capoeira, seen far too little in film or TV, but again the issue of how action sequences are orchestrated. I don't think Strathie's costume design or the work of the hair and makeup artists are inherently bad; I think their contributions, like all else here, were guided to the seediest, most blunt, most kitschy, and irritating ends they could be. Even the music, both Klaus Badelt's score and select songs on the soundtrack, are fine in and of themselves, but employed to ends that are actively irritating and far too on the nose.

The production design and art direction range from earnestly fetching to excessive. For the most part I think the cast is fine, and in the very least they try to imbue their performances with sincerity that is generally far too lacking in the proceedings. All the same, there's a tinge of inauthenticity in the acting, even from the likes of Frances Conroy, Lambert Wilson, or Sharon Stone, that I can only assume is owed to the senseless overcooked ethos that defines every last element. And as for Halle Berry, well... In some moments we see the refined personality, range, and otherwise skills that we know she possesses and has demonstrated elsewhere to great success. In some moments she's at least clearly having a good time. In too many others, however, Berry is overacting with a frenetic, overcharged bluster that's just plain outrageous. Sure, we can chalk this up in part to the way Catwoman is written in the first place, and above all Pitof's direction and the overall slant of the production are a predominant factor. Still, she leans so hard into the dishonest swagger that she becomes a controlling focal point of it - its victim, to some extent, but just as surely its driving force in some measure. Golly, is this regrettable.

Have I mentioned the picture's embrace of forensic pseudoscience, the favored instrument of crime shows on TV and untrustworthy state agents in real life? Have I mentioned the significant practice here of the male gaze at every opportunity - never sexy, only ever sleazy - into which the final look of Strathie's design directly feeds? The root concept of every component part is at least baseline suitable, if not also inventive, clever, and or smart. For lack of mindful care, however, or perspective, there is glaringly, appallingly little about this that actually comes off well. Through to the very end this is too often altogether boorish or obnoxious, and far too little entertaining. What kernels of value it can claim aren't nearly enough to rise above the overwhelming crudeness and bawdiness of what it ultimately represents. It turns out that 2004's 'Catwoman' really is That Bad.

I see what it could have been. That is it not what it is. I'm glad for those who do get more out of this than me or many others. Unless you have a special reason to watch, however, then Pitof's 'Catwoman' is a feature that's best left to that wing of the vaults that no one talks about.

Catwoman is a movie that has nothing to do whatsoever with the Batman universe. This stand alone movie could have easily been a contender to be decent and it was hyped to be one of the biggest movies of 2004, however the end result is an epic failure. Apart from the nonsensical plot, take away the dark themes of the movie and this could have easily been aimed at children.

In this disaster of a movie, Halle Berry plays Patience Phillips (who has no place in the Catwoman/Batman universe), a meek and shy graphic designer for Hedare Beauty run by the husband and wife team George Hedare (Lambert Wilson) and Laurel Hedare (Sharon Stone). When Patience inadvertently stumbles upon a corporate conspiracy the company is hiding, Laurel Hedare order Patience killed. When she almost drowns in a drain, she is mysteriously brought back to life by a cat and Patience is transformed into an wild and untamed woman with cat like abilities. With her newfound transformation Patience becomes Catwoman, a sleek and stealthy creature balancing on the thin line between good and bad.

Halle Berry was terrible in this movie. I was in disbelief that Halle Berry would appear in this rubbish. Catwoman also saw the beginning of the end of Halle Berry's career, particularly after she was riding high from the success of X Men (2000), Swordfish (2001) her landmark Academy Award winning role for best actress in Monster's Ball (2001), and the coveted role as a James Bond girl alongside Pierce Brosnan in Die Another Day (2002). Since the box office failure of Catwoman, Halle Berry's career has never recovered. And Sharon Stone as the lead villain could not even salvage her career with an awful performance. Sharon Stone's glory days are well and truly over and her performances in Total Recall (1990), Basic Instinct (1992) and Casino (1995) seems like a distant memory. I was shocked that screen writing team John Brancato and Michael Ferris were involved in this atrocity. They both certainly have done better work in their career with The Game (1997), Terminator 3: Rise of the Machines (2003), Terminator Salvation (2009) and Surrogates (2009). Director Pitof has also disappeared without a trace from Hollywood.

When I will think of Catwoman/Selina Kyle I will always think of Michelle Pfeiffer who immortalised Catwoman in Batman Returns (1992). Recently Anne Hathaway turned in an excellent performance with her take on Catwoman/Selina Kyle in The Dark Knight Rises, and for TV audiences Camren Bicondova plays a young Selina Kyle in the 2014 television series Gotham. Rewinding to the Batman TV series (1966-1968) and the movie (1966) , Catwoman was played by Julie Newmar, Lee Meriwether and Eartha Kitt respectively. The 2004 version of Catwoman should be banished forever from existence.

Catwoman is so bad it complements kitty litter. No wonder this deserved the title of being the worst movie of 2004.

1/10.

review_title: One of the worst films ever made.

It's all about girl power. That's why there's a female arch-villain who is head of the evil skin-care product line.

Did I mention the skin-care factory? Unfortunately for me, I saw this on the plane so aside from opening the emergency release lever, there really was no escape. Although I honestly think death at 30,000ft is the more humane choice of the two.

I tried to sleep through it but I can't sleep on planes, the only time I ever got some solid sleep on a plane was when I saw Kate and Leopold.

Like I said, this is truly one of the worst films ever made, avoid, avoid, avoid!

review_title: A travesty of a comic hero
review_detailed_main:
Yes, I too saw this movie. It's a travesty. For one thing I think they ripped off DC Comics, because Selina Kyle is the REAL name of Catwoman. And last time I checked, she was a thief who stole from wealthy people, not an artist. Catwoman used to be one of my favorite DC Comics characters because she wasn't a hero, but she wasn't really a villain either. And by the way, the REAL Catwoman NEVER acted like a REAL cat. She may have had cat-like reflexes, but she was still as human as Batman/Bruce Wayne.

This movie actually lowered my IQ. I dunno why, but I saw it twice, at the time I thought, "Hey, maybe it'll be better the second time around." I was wrong. As for the story, god forbid something in this movie make sense. I believe Carlos Mencia has a phrase for something like this, "Dee Dee Dee!"

All said, I rate this movie a 1, because they won't allow me to rate any lower.

Why critics trashed this film is beyond me. It's actually quite entertaining. Berry pulls off the role very nicely, and Stone portrays the villainess with a nice, icey edge. Bratt is good as the hero/cop as well. The soundtrack is kicking and the story line is never boring. The most unfortunate thing I can think of saying about this film is that it had the misfortune of opening up against bigger blockbuster films like the Bourne Supremacy and I, Robot, while Spiderman 2 was still going strong also. This is a good little action-type movie that should be given a chance. Ignore the critics (I ALWAYS do) and check it out for yourself. Though this film is no comparison to Star Wars in any way shape or form, I read somewhere that critics (as usual) trashed that too. See it and then decide for yourself.

I beg to differ with the critics as well as most of the public (this probably means I am wrong, but this is my opinion and I will keep it nevertheless). I found this to be a decent, above average superhero movie. I found it was very well filmed (the camera is excellent, there are many very innovative angles used), the special effects are good (which cannot be said for many much better rated movies), the sound is very good and the acting is more than passable.

Yes, the story is simple to the point of being naively stupid, the screenplay and dialog are full of clichés, but then again, this is not an adaptation of Ezra Pound, this is a superhero movie, and for that is exactly what it is supposed to be; a well made cartoon!

Oh, and on one thing I do agree with Ebert... Halle Berry is gorgeous! It is hard to think of any actress on screen ever that has emanated so much sex-appeal, such sheer beauty. She was wonderful to watch, and there is nothing wrong with that, is there?

There have been many movies made from comic books lately. Some good (Road to Perdition, Spiderman, The Hulk and some of the Batman flicks). Some bad (Daredevil and some of the Batman flicks). Where these movies succeed is in there simplicity and straightforwardness in its storytelling. Where they fail is found in their excess. Catwoman is a failure because they took a good actor(Benjiman Bratt, Alex Borstein, Frances Conroy) and paired them with gorgeous but lukewarm talent like Halle Berry and Sharon Stone. Couple these casting faults with an overuse of CGI tricks, gaudy set design and cutesy music video moments and you have this movie. The plot line put forth by Ms. Conroy's character should have been the focus of the movie instead of putting so emphasis on the damned costume and the overbearing soundtrack and violence. Don't get me wrong, I enjoyed watching Ms. Berry and Ms. Stone having their cat-fight but I think that the audience is smart enough to have had a little "story" thrown their way. It's a crying shame that so much money and time was wasted for so little return.

review_title: This has nothing to do with Batman!!!! (Possible Spoilers)

review_detailed_main:
Okay. There's been a lot of debate in the comments on whether this movie is as poor as some claim. I'm one of those people who say it is. I do not think this movie deserves even its current rating. There's this thing I can't stand in a movie: A line or an event of extreme idiocy or stupidity. It's like someone stabs me with a needle every time something simply too stupid happens on the screen. A typical blockbuster has a few of these, Catwoman had a years worth. The movie is incredibly stupid. The characters are stupid, the dialogue is incredibly stupid, the action scenes are stupid and the entire scenario of the movie is truly stupid. Stupid.

In addition, the direction is horrible, Halle throws her worst performance I've seen to date, other actors are awful and the movie has no "atmosphere" to speak of, it feels incredibly pretentious and poorly written from start to finish.

Absolutely dreadful. 1 point for the outfit and the laughs.

In Catwoman, Halle Berry plays Patience Prince, a shy, unassuming graphic artist at a cosmetics company. Prince lack the backbone to stand up to others, and generally stays out of everyone's way until she discovers that a new product has potentially lethal side effects that are being hidden from the public. Yep, something is rotten in Denmark.

Prince is then found out by the bad guys and left to die, but she not only recovers but also absorbs some mystical cat powers. Now armed with catlike agility and dexterity, she clads herself in a cat-eared cap and CGI whip and goes out to get revenge in her new identity as a cat-burglar anti-hero. Conflicts ensue, she meets romantic interest Bratt, and dukes it out with Sharon Stone.

This movie is thoroughly and unapologetically dumb. With silly dialog, cardboard acting and some pretty mediocre action sequences, Catwoman is much more corn than comic book. Halle Berry is a talented actress, but in Catwoman she acts likes she's on auto-pilot, and only drags the whole thing down further.

Sure, Catwoman was never supposed to be a Casablanca, but even a popcorn movie needs intelligence and fun. Catwoman is just a sprawling mess. If extreme-campiness is up your alley it may be worth a look, but otherwise don't waste the ten dollar box office fee on this turkey.
This film has nothing to show for appart from casting Hale Berry

review_title: Cat woman: Sour milk. Warning spoilers.
You've Got To Be kidding Me right? No, you're not

review_detailed_main: The problem with this movie is not that it's bad, but it's predictable and unmemorable. A couple months after this movie I've seen this movie, I probably won't remember a thing about it, because there's nothing about it that makes it stick out amongst other flicks in the superhero genre--unlike "The Punisher" which came out earlier this year and was much more edgy and original in its approach. I don't know anything about the director's background, but my guess is he had his start in music videos. "Catwoman" pretty much has the same hyper-kinetic, MTV-style direction that we see in way too many recent movies. Some of the shots are obviously computer-generated, and definitely took me out the movie. Halle Berry gives as good a performance as possible, but there's not much you can do with mediocre material. None of her one-liners are witty or funny. "What's wrong? Cat got your tongue?"--yeah, wow, that's a good one.

Halle Barry did an excellent portrayal of cat woman. In fact, she brought new dimensions to this fictional character in regards to being a dynamic, round, intelligent, caring, loving, extremely attractive, athletic, growing woman.

The other characters in the movie were perfect for their respective roles, especially cat woman's beatable nemesis.

There was some speckles of humor by one of the characters that was worth wile. It was actually funny. I really enjoyed all the elements (characters & props) that forged this film. They (all involved) did a pretty good job on this movie despite what renown critics say.

I would recommend this DVD to be introduced to anyone's collection.

Oh, another great thing...there was no sex scenes as most movies tend to deem a necessity for sales. This is also encouraging to those woman (and men) who struggle with accepting who they are. There are messages here (in the movie). There are even some faith connotations as well. See if you can catch it.

review_title: OMG Stay AWAY! Worst movie in history of man kind!
review_detailed_main:
Oh my god First of all let me start with one thing: The Cat Woman is not Afro-American. I see a few people talking about an alternative Afro Cat Woman from the Comics as well as from an old TV series; OK, so, let me explain to you people: Spider Man had six arms, became evil, died, resurrected, was black in an alternative reality, was a woman and so many other ALTERNATIVES, but Spider-Man, the original character from the Amazing Spider-Man comic book is brown haired, blue eyed skinny looking guy, the other versions lasted for ONE comic book only as an alternative deal, that is it period. It does not make him Afro-American in any way, so, don't do a movie about it. The very same thing happens with Cat Woman  she had alternative stuff, but the original character IS a foxy Blonde Blue Eyed woman. Once the director and casting crew decided to change that, they lost millions of fans including me. It is a stab in the back, a betrayal worthy of trial! Don't mess with the originality of an ancient character, please, don't ever do that again.

Now, lets just say the idea of a Cat Woman movie is cool nonetheless, so I did managed to watch it, I am a fan of her (Cat) after all. After ten minutes of watching, I noticed I had a pain head and realized I was going to regret renting this for my entire life, and when the movie ended I did.

Halle Berry is pretty? Sure, but is she as beautiful as a Blonde Blue Eyed woman? Hell no, and I noticed this movie needed a foxy blonde, it hell needed it a lot and Halle did not manage to replace it, not in a million years. Again, the Cat woman is Blonde Blue Eyed, so, when you change that, you kill the best feature of the movie. Don't listen to the very few people who say the "blonde" type is a 2k stereotype, old stuff I am sorry but it is not, if the Cat Woman was Blonde I am sure this one would get at least a 6 from me.

Everyone wants to see a foxy Blonde in a costume like that; now you take that away... You simply have nothing interesting, period. OK, so, enough with the blonde deal, lets say you are a fan of Halle Berry, cool; you can see her as the Cat Woman. Don't even dream amigo! Even if you CAN manage to tolerate her presence (Impossible to me ever since she boycotted the X-Men 2 and 3 because she is "An Oscar Winner... boohoos"), you still have the worst movie ever made in history of man kind at your television. Why is the worst of all? Because of Halle and Sharon acting as well as everything else.

I find this very disturbing because the director or "I don't know who else" actually thought that the mere presence of Halle would be enough to make it look good, and again this proved that I am right about her "not deserving her Oscar", because her acting in this movie was the worst in history of man kind. I have never seen anything like IT in my entire life. I am not joking, if you watch this movie, you will notice that Halle makes some strange faces as if she was acting in a blue screen or as if she was staring into the "void" the entire movie, looking like a robot or "retard" woman. The lack of a decent acting is so disturbing that you will start to feel like watching one of those tapes your own kids do at home. The other reasons are the lack of special effects, good fighting scenes, action, good sound effects and the most important of all: A Story. I don't know what went wrong in there, it is not the low budget  just check The Punisher, the lowest budget movie ever made and yet it looks so amazing, the actors did a superb job  So, maybe it was the presence of the short haired Sharon Stone (Someone should tell her, she is looking like a dude) who lacked to fish the blonde lovers like me, or it was the painful acting of them both, or the fact that they changed the ethnicity of one of the coolest female characters of the comic book, leaving us only Elektra and the Wonder Woman as a "true to the fans" crossover.

It is a pity that an Oscar winner like Halle acted so badly, disturbingly I am starting to think she never deserved the statue, as it was not her first bad job, just go and see her on X-Men 3, she had a terrible performance as well  Maybe she is falling in her career, who knows? For your own sake, don't bother for this one, even if you are a fan; seriously, there is nothing to see there, other than a pain head.

review_detailed_main:
I've seen this movie on my DVD with all special features on it and and I must say that this movie isn't quite what I expected to be. review_title: Not a bad movie at all

review_detailed_main:
Catwoman has become one of the most despised films of 2004. Critics and fans alike mauled and hissed at it, criticizing everything from Halle Berry's acting to Pitof's direction. It even got 7 Razzie nominations. However after viewing this film on DVD, I was pleasantly surprised. The film has numerous flaws but its not as bad as its made out to be.

Halle Berry plays Patience Phillips, shy artist by day, bank-robbing Catwoman by night. There is a plot, but it quickly takes a backseat to shots of Halle Berry strutting around in a S&M suit. While its not her best performance, Berry convincingly balances the two personalities of her character. Its the supporting cast where the movie begins to fall apart. Sharon Stone is terrible in her role as the villain, she either spits out her lines or overacts the entire picture. The other characters are not developed enough to care.

While one good actress can carry a decent movie, Pitof ruins the film with heavy editing and terrible use of CGI. The fight scenes are so choppy that they allow a man to stand in as Halle Berry's stunt double. Other scenes such as Catwoman on the motorcycle look like the camera was tossed in a laundry machine. And while Halle Berry looks gorgeous in the Catwoman costume, she is replaced half the time by a CGI catwoman that seems to be able to defy gravity at will. When the lead actress is the only thing a film has going for it, its best not to replace her with a digital puppet.

Overall, this film is watchable if only to see Halle Berry strut in the Catwoman costume. Other than that, its a turkey. Save your money and buy something else.

The title of this review speaks for itself, this is probably the worst DC movie ever made, the plot is stupid as hell and it has no intention of telling the story of the comic books.

The only good thing about it is the fact that it's really funny, but not because it's trying to be funny...

I remember a few years ago I was flying back to LAX, and the in-flight movie was "Waterworld" starring Kevin Costner. I had read that it was one of the worst movies ever made, and wondered "How bad could it really be?" Well, after the first 10 minutes, it REALLY was that BAD. So I took a nap for while, then proceeded to watch the remainder of movie without the headset on. Amazingly, the movie was now watchable and somewhat entertaining. This anecdote is a long about way of saying that "Catwoman" will someday be a great airplane movie sans the audio headset. Yes, this is a glaring indictment of a totally inept movie that wasted 90 minutes of my life. Granted I did see the movie to kill some time. Stupid me. A dear bud, Bobby, pointed this out to me. This vacuum of redeeming quality is completely unexpected given that Halle Berry as Catwoman is one of the most stunningly beautiful women to watch on screen. Benjamin Bratt as her torn romantic interest Detective Tom Lone is a great looking leading man and solid actor. The very hot and steamy Sharon Stone plays her evil best as aging cosmetics baroness, Laurel Hedare. However, all their star power can not overcome the incoherent and incomprehensible storyline. The movie is a mess. Director Pitof has a cutting edge visual style, and provides a cool textured score. Ultimately, this does nothing.

I do like stupid funny movies-- that would be intentionally stupid and funny movies. What I do find most annoying is unintentionally and ineptly stupid movies. This would be "Catwoman". It is a bad omen when the opening credits require an explanation later in the movie itself. The transformation of meek and mousy Patience Phillips (Berry) to the fierce Catwoman is plain dumb. Berry looks stunning in the costume, and obviously trained her body rigorously for this role, but this is all for not. Even if "Catwoman" had some quality gratuitous nudity, it would not have been able to salvage this train wreck.

Don't see this horrible movie. It is a complete waste of time, even if you are looking to waste some time. Really.

I think Michelle Pfeiffer played a better Catwoman. The big problem with this movie is its goal of emphasizing how supposedly sexy Halle Berry is. Michelle did it cooler, more subtle. She didn't go into its making, thinking, "Ok, I have got to put on a show for the world just how amazingly sexy I am." Halle's a pretty girl but doesn't strike me as exceptionally "sexy". Especially at the end of this one, with the way she walks away and cracks her whip, I think the movie got carried away with the whole "sexy" thing.

review_title: Film Abortion Makes Prison Rape a Viable Alternative

review_detailed_main:
As the other comment on this site said - don't necessarily believe the critics - it's worth forming your own opinion. This is by no means a good film, but i can think of many worse ways to spend a couple of hours - as far as bad films go, at least this one is in no way pretentious or boring.

OK so it is stupid (since when do cats know how to do kung fu/basketball /breakdancing/whip wielding/running up walls?) and the fight scenes are nothing but a series of incomprehensible fast cuts (presumably this was cheaper than sending Halle Berry on an intensive Kung Fu training course), but the actors and director do a reasonable job, and the film at least looks expensive.

The one thing i really don't understand is who came up with the plot in the first place. What superheroes need is a good super villain. And since comic book movies (particularly comic book movies starring Halle Berry in a revealing leather costume) are presumably mainly aimed at a male audience, who on earth thought that a couple of executives at a cosmetics company would make good bad guys? So the concept of the film was flawed from the start, but in my opinion i don't think that justifies the vitriol this film seems to attract..

I gave this movie a 2 out of 10, and i was being extremely generous. what kind of a movie has the evil arch-villain as the leader of a cosmetics company whose weapon to take over the world is......face cream that turns your face rock hard. it's truly sad how watery this movies was. also, did you notice that most of the background music had female vocals on it, as if trying to reinforce the pathetic lady-hero, a woman-can-accomplish-anything theme. now I'm not being a misogynist, but sometimes you shouldn't milk a cow till it dies of dehydration. the plot was immature, the dialogue so predictable, the acting so fake and forced, i hope this serves as a reminder to us about how important proper direction and focus is, and when it is not there, this is the kind of movie that materializes.

I LOVED this movie. It was a great action flick and as a start to a new series of movies, it couldn't have been better. The incorporation of the classical views of cats and women is very intelligently done, and the character of Patience is believable and smart.

She is an amazing super hero/villain. I have always adored the character of Catwoman, especially as the anti industry ecological activist. I like the direction they are taking the character. No longer simply a sexy counterpart of Batman, Catwoman has her own agenda, her own personality.

Halle is a very talented actress who brings to life a very complex character with both respect and innovation. The Catwoman idea is not used simply as a gimmick, it is a very believable and respectable transformation.

I doubted the casting when I first heard the movie was being made but now, I think that anybody but Berry would have been a mistake, she brought both glamor and humility to the role.

So, go see this movie and enjoy it for what it is. Don't compare it to other comic book movies because the character is not just a comic book character. She has grown beyond the confines of the page and has erupted on the silver screen as a powerhouse of action and sexuality, she is Catwoman hear her roar... and I for one, will be roaring along with her.

review_title: Wear your tin-foil hat for this one...

review_detailed_main:
I wasn't expecting much out of Catwoman, having heard it was abysmal. I only decided to watch it because I was recovering from surgery and needed something mindless. Perhaps that's why I was able to enjoy it. I mean, it is a terrible movie, the script is somewhat incoherent, the dialog is ludicrous and the special effects are silly rather than cool. But it is also a movie that is rather amusing, sometimes on purpose, more often by accident, and it moves pretty quickly. It's certainly more entertaining than The Incredible Hulk, which is an example of a bad movie that doesn't even manage to be any fun.

The general incompetence of almost every aspect of the film can at times bring it close to the level of an Ed Wood movie, but alas the film lacks Wood's pretensions to greatness, and rarely is so bad as to be laugh out loud funny (although it does happen a couple of times). The movie also manages a few legitimate laughs. So all in all, while I wouldn't want to watch it again, I don't regret watching it once.

Still, this must be the worst portrayal of Cat Woman. The most interesting conceptually was probably Michelle Pfeiffer in Batman Returns, even though I didn't think much of the movie, but for me catwoman will always be the fabulous Julie Newmar from the TV series.

Often you watch a film and think "This sucks so hard that I don't know where to start" but with Cat-woman the errors are glaringly obvious and easy to break down.

1) The score, the first thing that hits you when watching this film is that the score is completely inappropriate. The timing is off, it will kick in while someone is talking and kick in with heavy rock music when a couple is on a date. When someone takes their jacket it off it will sound like the final scene from cliffhanger before a much more uneventful scene. If there was any chance of immersing the viewer in this film, the score was the final straw.

2) The choreography, I'd like to think for Halle Berrys sake that someone else told her to move and walk like that when she is in 'cat-woman' mode. (In my opinion) The way cat-woman walks is not provocative, confident and carefree... it looks silly and ruins any chance of cat-woman being a decent protagonist.

3) This history of cat-woman. I'm not a marvel/batman expert so I don't know much about this but I do know that Michelle Pfeiffer in Tim Burtons Batman universe... well she rocked as an incredibly dark and mentally disturbed cat-woman. The 'sex in the city' cat-woman created in this film just doesn't paint the same sortof picture at all and anyone over the age of 25 will remember Michelle Pfeiffers cat-woman well. While I'm at it, there are strange undertones to the dialogue when explaining cat-woman in the film, like instead of just making someone that goes a bit crazy and gets bitten by a cat they start trying to make a statement about how a woman behaves without hibitions. All a bit too much for me.

4) The CGI. CGI is heavily used in this film, every single time the cat-woman does something that would seem inhuman they revert to a CGI version of Halle Berry in costume - OK, fair enough. Problem: The CGI isn't high quality enough for the close ups, they zoom right into the face of the fake Halle Berry asif to make it as obvious as possible that you're watching something that isn't real. Six years later they're just about got a believable Jeff Bridges in Tron 3D, why at that time they thought to do this I don't know. The over use of CGI continues with the use of over-zoomed shots and at one point even a CGI ferris wheel. Minutes later they use a real life version of the same ferris wheel, all seems a bit strange to me.

5) The acting. There are some good actors in this film but I found the acting to be unbelievable, there was chemistry between Halle Berry and the detective but little believability to their characters in my opinion.

I suppose it doesn't take much to get a green light in Hollywood these days. Catwoman wouldn't have been particularly difficult to pitch: Halle Berry crammed into a leather bodysuit, kicks ass, saves world. The End. Oh and she is handy with a whip. And has a bitch fight with Sharon Stone. Did I mention the leather bodysuit? Good - that ought to do it.

I guess some wag in the pre-production meetings may have tentatively ventured some concerns about lack of any plot or characterisation, but he was evidently shouted down and told not to be such a worrywart.

Much of the criticism levelled at this film is unhelpful and frankly misjudged. If you want to be intellectually stimulated go and watch Kubrick or Truffaut or, better still, read a book. This is a no-brainer, an event movie aimed at the school holiday market with tie-in video game potential. Anyway there is actually a fair bit of mileage in the idea behind Catwoman: The comic book traditionally transfers well onto the silver screen  Spiderman 2 opened recently to rave reviews, and the Batman franchise from which the character is taken has enjoyed immense critical and commercial success (the dreadful fourth installment Batman and Robin aside). Add to that Berry's considerable Box Office clout and you have what is surely a recipe for success.

Unfortunately though, even the best ideas will flounder if they are not fully thought through. Berry may be a good, nay Oscar-winning actress  better, certainly, than the catsuit's previous incumbent, Michelle Pfeiffer, and light years ahead of Eartha Kitt and Julie Newmar who rubbed up against the Dark Knight in the original sixties Batman TV show  but she cannot salvage anything from this.

She plays Patience Philips, a lonely, browbeaten graphic designer at a large cosmetics firm run by slick businessman George Hedare (Lambert Wilson) and his glamorous wife Laurel (Sharon Stone). After unwittingly stumbling upon a dastardly plot to thrust an anti-ageing product with hideous side effects on an unsuspecting public, Patience is bumped off only to be reanimated by a bunch of mystical moggies. Invigorated with feline zest, she seeks her revenge and falls for hunky cop Tom (Benjamin Bratt) en route. Cue lots of computer animated leaping about and plenty of catty anthropomorphism including Berry scoffing down tuna by the tinful, hissing at dogs and the obligatory milk moustache scene. Interestingly, Patience's alter ego is also surprisingly adept at basketball and kickboxing  not skills you would traditionally associate with the domestic pussycat.

Berry, as always, looks terrific, but she still falls someway short of Pfieffer's seminal Catwoman. The character in Tim Burton's Batman Returns is part of a wider ensemble. Fewer scenes enable Pfeiffer to cloak her Catwoman in ambiguity and maximise her impact  most memorably when she backflips effortlessly across a deserted lot, pauses and miaows sardonically as a massive building explodes behind her. It helps that she is directed by Burton, the master of the dark, acerbic fairy tale. Berry can count herself unfortunate that her movie is helmed by the curiously monikered Pitof, a Frenchman who seems to have arrived from nowhere (and, on this evidence, will be scuttling back there before too long).

Still, Pitof has obviously at least watched Batman Returns, for his movie simply lifts Catwoman's plot line out, dumbs it down and sets it to a pumping soundtrack. There is no heart, no ingenuity and there sure as hell isn't any depth. We learn nothing of Patience's past or why she has been selected to be blessed with superpowers. The villains of the piece are ludicrously unimpressive  you can imagine them being laughed out of the Global Confederation of Comic Book Baddies for sheer lack of imagination: 'So, what fiendish plans for world domination have you come up with? A super virus? Nuclear War, maybe?'  'Er, no, but we have developed a face cream that will give people a nasty rash'

Wilson is a tired, identikit evil genius, and Sharon Stone is more of a loony Bridgett Neilson clone than an exotic femme fatale. Neither can touch the sinister malevolence of Christopher Walken's Max Shreck or Danny DeVito's Penguin. Their plot is also so pathetic that Catwoman needn't have bothered with a dangerous, elaborate showdown to bring them to justice  simply reporting them to Watchdog would probably have done the trick.

Catwoman certainly isn't the car crash it could have been. Bratt's cop is pretty bland, but his chemistry with Berry is OK, and the computer animation whilst over the top makes for a slick cartoon landscape that is appropriate for a film like this. And, of course, if you can stomach the dizzying camera angles and stodgy dialogue, the pay-off is Halle Berry clad in leather and wiggling delectably. I would suggest that many red-blooded cinema-goers might well consider that a fair trade.

5/10

review_title: OK it's not horrible but in no way is it great either......
review_detailed_main:
and that is what you get when you watch Catwoman. Personally, I don't really care that this movie is not based on the original Selina Kyle character, because I never knew much about her anyway. So big deal, though I can understand why fan boys will be upset. so why not something different? Well firstly, let's cut to the chase. Who cares if Catwoman is not white! Halle Berry is a fine actress and deserved a chance to play Catwoman. However, in terms of her performance in this movie, her acting gets a bit sloppy when she is in the catwoman suit. Her character becomes this over the top sexy woman who cracks the whip too many times and who is given a laughable script and plot line to lead this movie.

Yes, my main problem with this movie is how silly the plot is. Halle Berry plays Patience Phillips (how they hell they come up with an absurd name such as Patience is anyone's guess) who is a shy, timid woman who works in a company that makes beauty products. When she overhears a secret in a new product called Beau Line and that if you use it, your face will deteriorate unless you keep using it, she is killed, then resurrected by some CGI cat, which is very obviously CGI. Now she has superpowers such as leaping from building to building, walking up walls like a cat and very clear vision.

**********MINOR SPOILER*************** OK, the villain in this movie, Laurel Hadare (Sharon Stone). I don't have a problem with Sharon Stone, but for one thing, she doesn't really have a superpower that can match Catwoman's abilities. Her ridiculous strength is having a face like stone because she has used that beau line product for years. Hence she can't feel pain. Ha ha ha ha ha. When she says the line in the movie in the climatic fight 'skin like living marble...and you can't feel a thing!' it is just plain ridiculous. And Catwoman is knocking the crap out of her and hitting not just her face but her legs and everything. I mean did Laurel apply the cream on her whole body as well? How come she can't feel pain in those other areas? It is really that absurd.

The editing in this movie is overdone. One of Catwoman's fight scenes with a guy outside a night club has probably over 40 images edited together so you can't follow the action properly. What's more, the action scenes are totally devoid of suspense or good choreography that it feels more like they made it up on the spot.

The soundtrack of the film is alright. I did like how they used the music but at other times the film feels more like a music video sometimes. The best scene is where Catwoman is walking and the camera slowly reveals her in her costume to the song 'whose in Control?' Benjamin Bratt who plays the cop and love interest seems a bit wooden and flat, and there doesn't seem to be a spark between him and Halle. I think they could have picked someone a bit better.

The character development of Catwoman is also not done very well because Patience seems to accept her being Catwoman very quickly before really coming to turns with her new identity. At times, it almost feels like she has a personality disorder and can't control who she is.

So this movie does have some fun moments and you really have to turn your brain off to enjoy this movie, otherwise you will just see how stupid the plot, script and in particular some of the lines given from Halle Berry are. It should have been a really more in depth movie.

What we know is that Patience is not the only Catwoman out there. She is in a line of previous women who were once catwomen, thus if a sequel had been made, she could possibly have met up with one of the other catwomen and teamed up or something. But that is never going to happen since they didn't do a good job with this one. Oh well, nice try guys.

This isn't the worst movie ever, there are so much worse. I think this was harshly criticised but it makes sense when you think about it. If you're going to take a character well known such as Catwoman on a $100 million budget and not do much with it that is unique or groundbreaking, then why bother? Halle Berry really should have thought about this before she took on the role. And she does try her best, but since she is trying to be both good and bad in terms of the nature of her character, we don't really see the bad side.

To the writers - for your next movie, please please do not make it about face cream whatever you do!

review_title: Doesn't deserve the stick it got
review_detailed_main: The infamous reviews from this particular title are more well known than the movie itself, as 'Catwoman' truly crashed and burned at it's release in 2004, both critically and commercially. However, I respect that it wasn't exactly a picture if marvel, but was it really that horrific?      Personally, I really do not think it was, and I believe that many who claim to hate this title, merely just jumped on the bandwagon in a hope of looking intelligent. I really do realise that it isn't exactly good, and many aspects would drastically need to be altered, such as the following:      Firstly, as a huge comic and more specifically Batman fan, Warner Bros did have to realise that by creating a comic book adaptation, their main target audience and more importantly domestically paying audience, would be  (wait for it) the comic book fans. For example, people will pay to see Selina Kyle, in a Gotham city based escapade. But we got Patience Phillips in some hi-tech LA or something or other. That's not what the audience wants to see, it sparks the question, who are they aiming this at?      As well as this, the storyline was a bit weak; killer beauty creme? Not exactly the works of a great mastermind, let's be serious. The plot was all over the place and a bit weird, making it hard to link onto one part of the story.      And lastly, the acting. Halle Berry sparked as the cat, but simmered as the girl. Her performance was absolutely cringy in some places, but she still did have her moments.      Okay, rant over. Now to shed some praise on the poor thing.      The effects were great, and the action sequences were fun and exciting. I do think that, that was nicely done indeed, especially with the cat like movements of Halle Berry jumping around, and the camera angles were impressive too. I also think that the sticky RandB music created a svelte mood whenever Catwoman walked onto screen, and it really helped spice up the on screen action too.     So, overall, we have a movie far from perfect, but also far from terrible, which is why I've given it a 5, because it really is slap bang in the middle. It's nothing special, but it's not disastrous.

review_title: Definitely one of the inferior comic book movies of the decade
review_detailed_main:
This Batman spin-off, as I'm sure you know, has been very poorly received in general. I missed its theatrical run back in 2004, but that's certainly NOT something I regret! I never even knew of the film's existence until sometime later. Now that I've seen it, unlike many others, I certainly don't hate it with a passion, so I can't join the many who have voted 1/10 for it. However, it's definitely a disgrace compared to several other comic book movies of the decade, and I can still pretty much understand all the hate.

Patience Phillips is a shy woman, constantly down on herself, who works for Hedare Beauty as a graphic designer. One night, she happens to overhear a conversation, and learns the truth about the company's new anti-aging product, how it will have dire results if one stops using it! When they realize that she has found out their evil secret, they chase after her and try to kill her! Eventually, they succeed, but Patience is brought back to life by a cat! After this, however, her life is a lot different! The cat has given her new superpowers, and now she is not a hero, not a villain, but somewhere in between! She is now Catwoman, and she plans to find out who is responsible for her death so she can get her vengeance! Soon, she ends up causing a lot of trouble in the city, and may pay the price for it!

I never expect the scripts of these comic book movies to be absolutely flawless, but do expect them to be at least half-decent, and the script for "Catwoman" isn't even that. It's a very juvenile one! Halle Berry certainly can act, but she puts on a poor performance in her starring role here, obviously because she didn't have a good script to work with. Her character does some pretty ridiculous things after being rescued, such as drawing a silly picture of her boss and eating cans of cat food. Clearly, Berry realizes how bad she is in this film, and how bad this film is, as she appeared to accept her Razzie "Award" for Worst Actress! The film is also rather poorly directed, with some rather cheesy action sequences, though you could probably find worse action sequences in "Power Rangers". Certain scenes in "Catwoman" may be so bad that they're almost amusing, but not quite.

I'm sure pretty much everything I've said about this movie has been said before, but I really don't know what else there is to be said. Now, much worse excuses for movies have seen the light of day, and I may not agree 100% with the extremely low rating for this one, but since it is pretty bad overall, I can't complain too much about that rating. Changing Catwoman's name from Selina Kyle to Patience Phillips is not a big deal, but all the flaws that I've pointed out are. Unless you're really curious, there's probably no point in seeing this film, but even if you are curious, you might regret it! If you want a good comic book movie, I strongly suggest you look elsewhere. Fortunately, one good thing I can say is kudos to Halle Berry for taking her Razzie and giving a funny acceptance speech! I guess she has a good sense of humour.

review_title: 1 hour 39 minutes of my life that I will never get back...

But, to be honest, I really don't think it's worth my time. What I will say unequivocally is this: The script is 6th grade level at best. The story-line is amateur-hour. The special effects, action scenes, and fight choreography are a joke...totally boring, fake, and generic. The final nail in the coffin? The acting is embarrassing. We want comic book adaptations that are worthy of their franchise and our hard-earned dollars. This steaming pile of dung is neither. Avoid at all costs.

The CG effects are not done well, they look overly cartoony and are used far too much; for example whenever there is a fly-by shot of the city a model would have looked a lot better. All in all, there is nothing about this movie worth watching if you are a film fan.. unless of course you are a red-blooded American male, then at least there is Halle Berry ;)

I sat down in 2022 to watch the 2004 movie "Catwoman" for the second time since it was released. Why? Well, because I only vaguely remembered the movie, well honestly, I remembered Halle Berry as the Catwoman character, and that was about it.

The storyline in "Catwoman", as written by Theresa Rebeck, John Brancato, Michael Ferris and John Rogers, is sort of a mixed bags of nuts. If you sit down to watch "Catwoman" with the notion of it being a DC movie with the Selina Kyle character and watching a movie tied in with the "Batman" universe, then you will be sorely disappointed. Because that just simply isn't what director Pitof delivered with this 2004 movie. If you, however, sit down to watch "Catwoman" with the notion of it being a somewhat cringeworthy movie based very loosely on the DC character of the same name, then you might actually find a shred of enjoyment in this movie.

I have to admit that I had expected it to be a DC-based movie, so I found the movie somewhat of a swing and a miss. But if you step back and look at it objectively, and forget all about DC and Selina Kyle, then "Catwoman" is a decent enough movie. Sure, it had flaws and such, but it does make for some cheesy enough entertainment.

Personally I didn't care much for the costume that they opted to strut Halle Berry around in here. The costume was way too revealing and made very little sense for someone to wear, especially for someone on the edge of the law, as in doing robberies, fighting criminals and such. Sure, I can see that there is some appeal to a certain demographic audience by having Halle Berry running around scantily clad, but it just was too tacky.

The acting performances in the movie were fair enough. I know that the acting performances have been disliked broadly. But I actually found them to be adequate enough when you take into consideration the shortcomings of an improperly written script and storyline. The movie has some good talents on the cast list actually, with the likes of Halle Berry, Sharon Stone, Benjamin Bratt, Lambert Wilson, Frances Conroy and Byron Mann.

Visually, then I found "Catwoman" a bit too gritty and dark, and the underlaying references to matters of an adult content was just growing tired really quickly. Again, not the best of choices for the movie. The special effects in the movie were okay, not great though, but passable enough to make the movie watchable.

While the 2004 movie "Catwoman" is not a particular great cinematic gem, then it actually makes for an adequate enough, although somewhat corny and cheesy, viewing pleasure. I have, after all, seen the movie twice now since 2004.

My rating of "Catwoman" lands on a bland five out of ten stars.
