review_title: It's not as bad as all that
review_detailed_main:
Not only is Catwoman not a disaster, it's not even the worst superhero film of the year. Not that Catwoman is particularly great, but it's not as bad as everyone is saying, and in fact, it's fairly average. That's not an accomplishment, but for a film that should have by all rights been a disaster, it's a bit of a surprise.

Halle Berry, of course, stars as Patience Phillips, whose introduction and storyline largely follows the territory Tim Burton laid down over a decade ago with his take on the character; Patience is a shlep who is under-confident and under-appreciated (as if someone looking like Halle Berry could turn out that way) and whose best friend Sally (Alex Borstein) always has to push her into everything. Together they work for Hedare cosmetics, run by George Hedare (Lambert Wilson, the guy who played the Merovingian in the bad Matrix films) and his bitch of a wife, Laurel (Sharon Stone). Much like in Burton's version, Patience finds out something she's not supposed to and takes an unfortunate spill that ends her life. Of course she's brought back to life by some sort of cat-magic (it's explained in the movie) and becomes the feral, ferocious Catwoman.

Though it's a bit of a stretch to see Berry playing a frump, I have to congratulate whoever did her hair and makeup, because her varying looks fit the character's state of mind perfectly, and she seems just at home playing wimpy Patience as she does over-the-top Catwoman. Stone to me is the single most piece of ironic casting in ages; she plays a model who's being pushed aside due to her age and is desperate not to be put out to pasture. You'll also find some genre faces in some bit roles  Peter Wingfield miscast and strapped with an American accent as a scientist, and the Asian guy from Earth: Final Conflict as one of Stone's stooges. And of course, there's leading man Ben Bratt, playing Detective Tom Lone, who at least has the good manners to be interested in Prentice before she dons her dominatrix gear.

Borstein and Berry get on well, and there is some real chemistry between Berry and Bratt, a warmth there that makes their flirtation believable. Catwoman swipes a scene from Daredevil, when Patience and Tom play hoops; it reminds you of the Matt/Elektra sparring scene at the playground, but this one's more fun and displays a lot more chemistry. In fact, the movie is pretty enjoyable right up until they decide that Berry has to dress like a stripper and act like a whore  and there Catwoman goes right out the window. No matter how you try to play the character (and Berry tosses subtlety aside in a flash), the Catwoman outfit is so outrageously stupid that it is simply impossible to take seriously. That Berry chooses a few times to try to channel Eartha Kitt  possibly the worst choice for a screen Catwoman ever  doesn't help things (any acting choice made to emulate any performance on the old Batman TV show is just a bad idea in general). The outfit single-handedly kills the film, though admittedly the crazy CGI stunts don't help much. The action is also wildly over the top, with Catwoman hopping around the place with greater speed and agility than Spiderman.

Actually it's a shame, because those involved went to a great deal of trouble to draft a cogent mythology for the character, even down to the silly mask she wears, and they spent a fair amount of time trying to establish the bipolarity of Catwoman (a trait I've never cared for, but it is often a part of the character). The attempt at post-modern feminism is absurd, but a fair amount of work was put into this film in an attempt to establish a mythology (and probably a franchise). I was even impressed by the cosmetics company design work, because it was so terribly close to what real ones are like (and it was frustrating to think they had done so much with production design and dropped the ball on the most important costume in the entire movie).

Most of the acting is okay. Borstein always seems like she's having a good time, and Bratt plays a slightly warmer version of his Law and Order character. But he's a very likable guy, and you can see why Patience (or any woman) would be drawn to him. Stone overdoes it a little, but really, when has she not? The irony of casting her as a former model who has turned to stone (almost literally) to me far outweighs any problems with her performance, which are minor in any case. Berry herself overdoes the Catwoman vamp, and I wish she hadn't, because this might have actually been a wholly enjoyable film if she had reigned it in a little.

Catwoman is not a terrible film, though it misses its audience by a mile; it was obviously aimed at young women, but with that Striperella outfit, it's going to attract more men than gals. Actually I preferred it to the much more popular Spiderman 2; while this lacks a performance anywhere near Alfred Molina's Doc Ock, at least here the romance works, and much like Spiderman 2, a lot of the plot hinges on being able to buy into that. You can see some heat with Berry and Bratt; Dunst and Maguire sometimes seem like they filmed separately and were paired only in editing. Catwoman's probably going to be forgotten (or on deep discount on DVD by the end of the year), which is maybe not a fate wholly undeserved, but I've seen many worse films this summer. I can't really recommend this, but I can't tell you to stay away, either. All I can tell you is that it's being unfairly maligned by a viewing public who championed two films of monumental mediocrity masquerading as fun to the tune of almost a billion dollars this summer; you do the math.

review_title: "Catwoman" is a 2004 superhero film directed by Pitof and starring Halle Berry in the titular role. Despite featuring a beloved character from the DC Comics universe, the film
review_detailed_main:
"Catwoman" is a 2004 superhero film directed by Pitof and starring Halle Berry in the titular role. Despite featuring a beloved character from the DC Comics universe, the film received largely negative reviews from both critics and audiences alike.

The story follows Patience Phillips (played by Halle Berry), a shy and insecure graphic designer who works for a cosmetics company. After uncovering a dark secret about the company's newest product, Patience is murdered by her employer. However, she is mysteriously revived by an ancient Egyptian cat, granting her enhanced agility, strength, and feline instincts.

Embracing her newfound powers, Patience adopts the persona of Catwoman and sets out to seek revenge on those who wronged her. Along the way, she encounters a charismatic detective named Tom Lone (played by Benjamin Bratt), with whom she develops a romantic connection. However, as Patience delves deeper into her dual identity, she must confront the true nature of her abilities and the forces that seek to control her.

Despite its intriguing premise and the star power of Halle Berry, "Catwoman" failed to deliver a compelling narrative or engaging characters. The film's over-the-top action sequences and lackluster special effects were widely criticized, as were its inconsistent tone and disjointed plot.

Additionally, the film's departure from the established lore of the Catwoman character, as well as its failure to capture the essence of the comic book icon, disappointed fans of the source material. Halle Berry's performance received mixed reviews, with some praising her dedication to the role while others found her portrayal lacking depth and nuance.

Overall, "Catwoman" is often regarded as a missed opportunity to explore the complexities of one of DC Comics' most intriguing characters. Despite its flaws, the film remains a curiosity for fans of superhero cinema, offering a unique take on the iconic Catwoman character that ultimately fell short of expectations.

review_title: Why did they bother with this?

I believe that had this movie avoided any connection with the comics it may have been a tad more successful, or at least appeared less of a failure. Why keep the Catwoman name if you aren't going to use any of the character's established history. At least then you wouldn't have had comics fans crying foul...

There appeared to be a few good nuggets in this film, but the bad choices, in my opinion, far outweighed the interesting ones. That costume, I mean, come on! If I was leaping around rooftops and doing all that gymnastic stuff I think I would prefer to have some more protection around my back and belly, and that stupid head mask made me wonder if she was hiding some kind of brain swelling in there.

Around the time the first photos of Halle in the skimpy costume came out, I recall reading it described as a costume fit for the porn version of Catwoman, very apt as far as I'm concerned.

And the bad kept coming, all those cheesy one-liners that would have been more at home in the sixties show than coming out of Halle's mouth, the plot was wafer thin and predictable, the fight scenes, which in a superhero movie should be one of the high points, were cut so fast that it was hard to tell what was happening often, or else the wire work and CGI were too obvious.

I rented this movie out of curiosity, to see if it really was that bad, and, well, it was... However some of the extra features on the DVD are interesting, especially the feature which has interviews with almost all of the people ever to portray Catwoman, and also many of the writers from the comics, all presented by Eartha Kitt, camping-it-up in a good way, unlike this lacklustre film.

Halle is one sexy kitten and brings a fresh feel to the character of Catwoman. She does seem to borrow certain mannerisms from past actors who played Catwoman, but she also shows that she was up to the challenge and comes across with a solid performance. The camera work was a bit over done and most of the time you could tell of the computer generated images of Catwoman doing her cat like moves. Even certain fight scenes seemed a bit awkward at times. Sharon's Stone's performance could have been better, but she was playing a vengeful, ex-model, who was being tossed aside for a younger beauty. How deep can you go when your playing a shallow character to begin with?

"Patience Philips" (Halle Berry) is an artist pretty much afraid of her own shadow who finds herself embroiled in a scheme by her cosmetics company employer with plans to distribute an unique anti-aging formula. Luckily for her, though, she also encounters Frances Conroy "Ophelia" and is soon in possession of some amazing powers giving her a ninja-like athleticism, strength, and flexibility - just like, well, a cat! The story itself it pretty lame, Sharon Stone is "Laurel", the scheming boss and Hollywood's flirtation with the totally hopeless Benjamin Bratt "Tom Lone" was still in full tilt as we embark on a truly comic book exercise in expertly choreographed but totally sterile set-piece action sequences. Halle looks great, lithe, supple and I like to think she was in on the joke all along; for a joke this definitely is.

Rating

3/10

Despite some decent camera work and visuals film has weak writing and acting (though Stone is ok). Unintentionally funny script relies too much on Special effects. Fight scenes don't excite.

A mess of a film.

review_title: I wish this movie had stayed an unrealised project
review_detailed_main: (sigh) For every American superhero film we have today there are about two lying in the superhero film graveyard. The Mandrake the Magician movie that was supposed to follow The Phantom, the Wachowschi's Plastic Man movie, The Justice League movie that ran out of money, hundreds of dozens of movies that could have been great but died during production and were buried in the superhero film cemetery. But this filmWhatever crime this movie commits is made worse by the fact that at one point in its life it could have been one of the best superhero films of all time. Let me explain. If you've ever had the misfortune to watch Tim Burton's 'Batman Returns' you will notice that the movie ends with a shot of Catwoman looking up at the Gotham sky even though we the audience earlier assumed her dead. This was because Burton and the studio were planning a spin-off film for the character. Now if you've seen 'Batman' and 'Batman Returns' one of the main problems with them is that Burton isn't interested in Batman and makes him take a backseat while he gives centre stage to his rogues gallery who are just the sort of freaks Burton is comfortable with. A movie devoted to one of those freaks would have had a lot of the good points of the Burton batman films but with the strength of being more focused. On top of that the best aspects of 'Batman Returns' were the Catwoman stuff so there was a lot of potential. Unfortunately 'Batman Returns' didn't make its money back and got Burton replaced with Joel Schumacher. Now if this had been the end of the story for the Catwoman movie it would have been fine, tragic but fine. But for some ungodly reason Warner brothers refused to let this film die and kicked it around development hell for years until they finally gave it to some no name director so the studio could spit out something to compete the marvel dominated Superhero scene. And so we got this unholy zombie of a movie that is a textbook example of how not just to write a bad female superhero movie but a bad movie with a female lead. Now before we get to the big problem with this movie I want to address the little ones. Firstly the production design is blandy bland bland, nothing interesting, nothing to right home about, just bland. This unappealing look is made worse by frequent use of really bad CGI. This movie has competent actors but none of them are interested in making a good movie so the performances aren't bad, bad can be fun, they're just weak. The plot is weak, the action is almost competent except the editing and CGI conspire to ruin it. The soundtrack is bad generic female black pop music (think discount versions of Beyonce or Brandy) that is obnoxious to listen to. Now if these were all the problems this would just be direct-to-video bad, nothing to compete with Hulk or Elektra just bad. There is one aspect of the movie that manages to single handedly make this one of the worst superhero movies of all time. The horribly misguided feminism. Dear lord this movie's treatment of women is awful! It tries to be all empowering and yet ever single female character in this movie is defined by her relationship to men. Worst still this movie has all the clichés you find in bad chick flicks; questionable morals, idiot characters, gay friend because men and women can't just be friends, an awkward bumbling lead, a dumb leading man. And then on top of that add all the clichés of a bad female superhero movie; objectification of women, sexist male villains, older women villains, girl power motifs and a costume designed more to excite juvenile viewers then it is to actually serve any function in combat. In summary this movie is decent idea filtered through the very worst clichés that cinema has to offer. This isn't even fun in a bad way it's just bad. Avoid at all cost.

review_title: Much better than you might be led to believe
review_detailed_main:
Yes, it's true. I sat down to watch this movie with the enthusiasm I usually reserve for MST3K films, expecting nothing but the worst movie of the century. You can imagine how disappointed I was then, when the film actually turned out to be quite entertaining.

Now, before you gasp in horror and wonder whether I've lost my scornful touch, I have to say the movie was far from perfect. But, compared to what I had been expecting, it was little short of amazing.

OK, so the story is silly, but is the idea that a woman who dies and is revived by a mystical cat any less ridiculous than someone being bitten by a spider and developing super-powers? I think not. The plot is simple, which actually serves to help the story, rather than hinder it, since you don't waste time wondering what the hell is going on. And Halle Berry is likeable enough in the main role that you can believe in her as the titular character. The action is fairly well done (see below for further thought on it) and keeps things moving along at a brisk pace.

Now the bad things.

Firstly, and once again I have to bitch about this because it is becoming a festering epidemic in Hollywood that must be stamped out! Stamp it out I say! - the CGI effects. They suck, quite frankly. At no point in the movie are you ever in any doubt whatsoever which Catwoman is a real person and which is CGI. It's doubly irksome here because, in addition to being glaringly obvious, the CGI animators still haven't got to grip with basic physics concepts like mass and momentum. Catwoman (whom we can assume weighs at least 120lbs or so) leaps about more like a demented flea than a cat and lands from great heights without even the slightest noise. Anyone who's ever owned a cat should be able to attest to the fact that they're anything but silent when running and jumping around. In fact the based on the CGI alone it would probably be better to rename the movie Monkeywoman.

Secondly, the action scene editing is just awful. I don't know who had the bright idea that, if you cut and chop scenes endlessly during an action set-piece it would make things look faster and more agile, but it don't work buddy! In several sequences - the basketball scene, the motorcycle ride and the "playing" with the cop above the theatre stage scenes the cutting and chopping is relentless. In most instances you get far less than a second to try and make sense of an image before it cuts to the next, then the next and so on. You must get thirty or forty cuts during a short scene. All it succeeds in doing is completely disorienting the viewer until they don't care what's going on, they just want it to be over. In fact, I actually felt a bit nauseous during the basketball scene (which is the first time you get the treatment). After that I got my spacelegs and could tough it out, though I still had a headache by the end.

A third annoyance were the cat traits that Halle Berry's character developed after she became Catwoman. She became fond of fish for a start. Well, that's stereotyping cat behaviour if ever I saw it. My cat preferred cheese to anything else. Catwoman also preferred milk and hissed at dogs. These might seem little things, but they were somewhat silly and aimed at cheap laughs. However, despite my fervent hopes all through the film, not once did she lick her genitals. Nor apparently, did she develop six nipples, or I'm sure her boyfriend would have noticed. Or develop a foul cat-breath with all the fish she was eating. So it amused me that she was given some, but not all, of the traits that cats are famous for.

Despite my lengthy gripes, the film was OK to watch and much better than I was fearing. If they'd have addressed the problems above, the film could really have been quite good. As it was, it was a harmless way to spend an hour and a half.

That was nearly three years ago, since that time I have seen this movie three times, and each of those three times I have unfortunately been left feeling cheated after seeing it. You see the movie Catwoman basically takes the character of Catwoman that I loved, dumps her into a bizarrely ridiculous universe revolving around make-up, gives her one of the most ludicrous costumes to date, and to top it all off just ruins every likable aspect of her character. So what's so bad about it? The action? The performances? The story? Well if I'm honest I'm not sure, the action has its moments despite hardly being amazing, the performances range from half decent from Halle Berry to stupid, Lambert Wilson, to just the plain horrifically ludicrously nasty performance by Sharon Stone. The story could have worked I suppose if given the proper treatment, even though the story about the main villain being evil because she isn't the front page girl anymore just never could work. No the biggest problem is the the fact that the script and direction basically mutilates this movie. This might have scraped mediocre had the camera bothered to stay still for two seconds and the dialogue been devoid of some of the worst clunkers in cinema history! Catwoman herself is a great character, and thankfully Halle Berry manages to make a terrible script not sound awful. Why she received the Razzie for Worst Actress is beyond me as she really does still have moments to shine. After she gets past the pathetic whimpering girl stage early on in the movie and gets serious she works very well. Of course her romance with Benjamin Bratt's policeman could never work, the pair have no chemistry and Bratt seemingly the charisma of a gnat. In fact the scenes where them two do a weird basketball sequence doesn't fell sexy as its meant to, in fact it just feels odd and misplaced. Sharon Stone clearly makes the biggest career mistake of her life in this movie though. Her character to be frank shouldn't exist in the first place, but just her performance itself is awful. I can't comment on her any more as she really is that hate-able in the movie.

Catwoman isn't the worst movie in the world, and the action does manage to make the movie rise a teeny bit above one of the worst movies I've ever seen. But the fact that no real effort has been placed into it just annoys me to the extreme. I would watch a Catwoman 2 on three conditions, Halle Very is back, the director and scriptwriter are fired, Sharon Stone swears that she will never act again, especially in a superhero movie. Then I'd consider watching a sequel, but since this was globally despised I really doubt I'd ever have to endure one anyway. So if you wanted to see this, take my advice don't, go watch Batman Returns instead.

review_title: Better than critics (and some IMDb voters) would have you believe.
review_detailed_main:
Halle Barry is excellent as Catwoman, especially in the difficult Patience/Catwoman transition. As Patience she is convincingly innocent, self-effacing and awkward; as Catwoman she is sexy, graceful, lithe and powerful. I can't find a thing to fault in Halle's performance, especially her amazing stunt work and extraordinary physical conditioning. She clearly put a lot of effort into preparing for this role and learning to move in a convincingly cat-like manner. I particularly like the way she handles her whip, which is reminiscent of the languid motion of a cat's tail or the quick strike of a paw.

As good as Halle is, overall the movie is very disappointing, a victim of both lack of imagination and heightened expectations. In fact, the only aspect of the movie that works is Catwoman herself. Her costume and diamond claws are wonderfully done, but she's all dressed up with nothing to do. While her backstory is well done, everything else seems like an afterthought. A comic book character needs a world of mystery, intrigue, danger and romance to inhabit. The story and setting need to take the viewer beyond the mundane. It needs to be larger than life, and that starts with imagining something extraordinary. The writers and director fail completely in this regard.

The contradictions inherent in a character of dual nature offer ample opportunity for dramatic tension, but the story fails to take any advantage of this, either. Nor does it bother to really explore Catwoman's danger-loving bad girl side.

The director, Pitof, is listed as an effects director on a number of French films and the last (and worst) of the "Alien" series. Clearly, he's not ready for prime time. Does an effects director even work with live actors? To judge by this effort you wouldn't think so. The difference between a blockbuster success and a complete flop can come down to hiring an inexperienced director to head an $85 million dollar project.

The bottom line: this is a watchable and entertaining film. Halle Berry's performance certainly makes it worth watching. I think anyone coming to it without high expectations will enjoy it.

An observation about votes and User Ratings: I noticed in the User Ratings that over 40% of voters gave this movie a "1". What's up with that? Considering how many genuinely crummy movies there are out there, the worst that can be said of Catwoman is that it could have been a lot better. I mean, really, you have to wonder how many of those votes are due to a herd-mentality "piling on". It's sad to think that this might be motivated in part by the star's race and gender.

review_title: A great concept gone awry because of directing
review_detailed_main: Catwoman is such a fantastic idea -- like Spiderman, Batman, Wonder Woman, etc. And yet, the directing of the this film was so music video-influenced and A.D.D. that it did a disservice to Halle Berry and Ben Bratt. Bratt and Berry's talents remain untapped for what they could have done. Additionally, the reduction of Berry's power to sexual attractiveness is a bummer -- and what are girls and boys to take from that? Spiderman is sexy, but not looking like a centerfold. Compared to Michelle Pfeiffer's Catwoman's walking the line of vulnerability, sexual power, and physical power, this presentation of the superhero/antihero feels like a disservice to the genre & to women and girls in general. The base story pits woman against woman over beauty and sexual virility -- what's that about? Is an aging gorgeous model really a sufficient nemesis? And finally, is the overall "moral" that a strong independent woman cannot have a relationship? These are questions I fear the filmmakers never asked themselves, and, though this movie could have been great, it instead does a disservice both to the actors and to the audience.

I can not believe that Warner Brothers would have made this film if they had read the screenplay. I also think that Halle Berry must not have read it as well. Sharon Stone most likely read this but she will show up for the opening of an envelope.

She works as a graphic designer for Hedare Beauty, a mammoth cosmetics company on the verge of releasing a revolutionary anti- aging product. When Patience inadvertently happens upon a dark secret her employer is hiding, she finds herself in the middle of a corporate conspiracy. What happens next changes Patience forever.

Trust me this is not only boring but stupid. Halle really can not pull the role. Sharon Stone is just mugging for the camera. I have no idea why Warner Brothers made "Pitof"the director. Trust me this film is so bad that nobody has ever let him direct anything again. That includes "Traffic".

review_title: If you were expecting Citizen Kane, then you deserve to be disappointed...

review_title: Don't be a puppet of the critics, see it for yourself first.
review_detailed_main:
After reading some horrendous (and I mean really, really bad reviews of 'Catwoman', I was definitely considering giving it a miss). I have to say that after having seen it, I am absolutely at a loss to words as to why the critics have mauled it so doggedly, and in my opinion unfairly. Were we watching the same film? What was so bad about it? Sure so the plot was on the thin side and the dialogue was highly camp, but other than that I can't see what has provoked the spewing of critical vomit all over this film. Halle Berry makes an adorable Patience, and displays her vulnerability believably and effectively. On the other hand, she really sexes up the screen as Catwoman with the witty one-liners, the hot costume and the raunchy whip cracking. Once again Halle has displayed her versatility.

This film is called Catwoman, the name should explain itself. I don't understand why people are ripping it to shreds or calling it laughable, e.g. as in the way Patience acts becoming Catwoman, i.e. the catnip incident (once), the hissing at dogs (once), the tuna (once, which I found to be amusing), the prancing around. What exactly did you expect her to do? How else do you act like a cat? How else does a human gain feline tendencies? Got any better ideas? I didn't think so. Yet we don't rip Toby Maguire to shreds when he shoots web from his arms (yeah like THAT makes sense.) There is clearly a double standard approach adopted by some critics, who contradict themselves more then they'd care to admit. I'm not saying I didn't enjoy Spiderman as well as this.

This not brain food and you don't have to evaluate your life after it but hey, people need that once in a while. It's a fun movie... The CGI was NOT bad, sure it was obvious at times that it wasn't Halle but for the most part it was done to a high standard. Let's be honest here and give credit where credit is due the cinematography is superb. It has such a visual allure, a dark, rich atmospheric look, and it is almost sexy to look at. The camera work is very original looking, kudos to Pitof, am I the first person to actually praise him? I think so. The scene where the Egyptian Mau brings Patience back to life is beautiful and picturesque. The music creates an epic mood.

Sharon was fun to watch as the 'past it', shallow, bitchy Laurel Hedare. Alex Borstein shined as Patience's best friend and Benjamin Bratt did the best that he could with what he was given as dialogue. Lambert Wilson plays his part, in the usual camp style, but does it to perfection. All in all the acting is not bad, and unless somebody has a personal vendetta against Halle Berry, it can't be said that she didn't put her all into the part. She was sizzling as Catwoman. One critic in particular said that she looked "as sexy as a hairball in the outfit". Either a jealous woman or a man with terrible taste in women must have written that. Halle has undeniable sex appeal in the part. The soundtrack is typical summer movie fare with the usual dramatic theme song, mixed with the current popular styles, hip-hop, r'n'b. This is after all a film that has to appeal to a teenage audience. The action scenes are exciting and well executed. The ending is suitably over the top but still entertaining. One scene that I thought was ridiculous was the basketball scene and some of the dialogue could have been much better, however the positives weigh out the negatives for me.

This is no Citizen Kane or Pulp Fiction but its no Gigli or Swept Away either. I have seen way worse comic book movies. Daredevil, Hell Boy and undoubtedly Hulk were worse than Catwoman. It is, on no level one of the worst films ever made. What were people thinking writing that? I went in with the lowest expectations possible for Catwoman and came out of the theatre having seen a supremely entertaining, undeniably above average film. Critics should be ashamed of themselves and audiences should not be puppets. This is worth seeing. There has been a 'Let's jump on the bandwagon' attitude regarding this film. One person bashes it and suddenly everybody does. I'm glad I went to see this film so I could make up my own mind regarding it. I usually do agree with critics but on this one, I beg to differ. Everybody is entitled to an opinion, you might not like mine, and I might not like yours but there is no need to be downright nasty and unfair when reviewing something. There is such a thing as being balanced. Oh and before people start complaining about the absence of Selina Kyle, and Gotham city, who cares, life is too short.

So if you want to some light, leave your brain at the door entertainment, go to see Catwoman. If you want to see a high drama Oscar category film, go to see something else. It's fun, sexy action-packed, camp, stylish summer fare. It is a step above the usual Hollywood fare in the style stakes. Pitof shows a typically stylish French attitude. Halle Berry does herself proud. If you want to be a gullible puppet, believe the 'we're failed artists', overly critical, intellectually snobby critics. I don't really care if that seems like a generalisation because it is most likely true. I bet many of them haven't even seen it. See it for yourself, and make up your own mind. I look forward to a sequel..
